course_title: Theory, Practice & Research: Musculoskeletal Phty - Lower Limb

learning_outcomes.description: Knowledge - Understand the pathologies, clinical presentation, scope of medical investigations, and inter-disciplinary management of a range of lower limb musculoskeletal conditions.
Psychomotor skills - Perform and record an effective and efficient interview of a client with a lower limb condition, and their carer where appropriate.
Psychomotor skills - Effectively and efficiently perform and record a range of assessment techniques and outcome measures for the lower limb.
Psychomotor skills - Effectively and efficiently perform and record a range of safe physiotherapy interventions for treatment and prevention, specific to a client with a lower limb injury.
Psychomotor skills - Effectively and efficiently prescribe evidence-based exercise to clients with a lower limb injuries and pathologies from initial injury to return to sport/work/function.

Understanding/Clinical reasoning - Interpret information from the patient interview to develop a physical examination plan and diagnostic hypotheses, and use results of thephysical examination to confirm/negate this.
Understanding/Clinical reasoning - Synthesise and analyse assessment findings and current research to design a management plan for a client with a lower limb condition.
Understanding/Clinical reasoning - Justify a physiotherapy intervention based upon clinical assessment, client goals and understanding of the literature.
Understanding/Clinical reasoning - Evaluate the effectiveness of your physiotherapy intervention.
Evidence-based practice - Source, interpret, apply and reflect on research/evidence to improve understanding and inter-disciplinary management of lower limb musculoskeletal conditions.
Evidence-based practice - Apply scientific evidence about lower limb pathologies and their assessment and management in a clinical context.
Reflection - Critically reflect on your management of clients with lower limb injuries and development strategies for self-improvement.
Reflection - Effectively provide constructive feedback to peer learners and suggest strategies to improve their practice.

assessments.task_description:
This practical exam will examine your ability to conduct effective and efficient components of a patient interview and physical examination on a patient with a lower limb injury/condition. Your exam will consist of the following two stations:

1. Patient interview.

2. Physical examination skills.

This exam will be conducted face-to-face, on-campus (St Lucia). 

Artificial Intelligence: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Feedback: You will receive individual written electronic feedback following the exam. If you would like further feedback, this request should be in writing to the course coordinator. Additional feedback will be provided within 14 calendar days.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The in-semester written exam will examine lecture and tutorial material from week 1 through week 5 of the course. The exam will be based on clinical cases. You will be given a number of client cases and you will be asked a series of questions about each case.

This exam will be conducted face-to-face, on-campus (St Lucia) and is a closed-book invigilated exam. 

Artificial Intelligence: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Feedback: Written and oral group feedback will be provided by the course coordinator. Requests for individual feedback must be submitted to the course coordinator.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will examine work covered in all of the course. You will receive 15 minutes of perusal followed by two practical exam stations:

1. Assessment and/or treatment of a client with a lower limb injury injury. 

2. Treatment of a client with a lower limb injury. 

Each station will be approximately 7 minutes long. 

This exam will be conducted face-to-face, on-campus (St Lucia). 

Artificial Intelligence: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Feedback: You will receive individual written electronic feedback following the exam. If you would like further feedback, this request should be in writing to the course coordinator. Additional feedback will be provided within 14 calendar days. End-semester practical exam marks will not be released until after the release of the final grade.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This exam will examine work covered in all of the course. You will receive 15 minutes of perusal followed by two oral exam stations. The oral exam stations will discuss your management of two different client cases with lower limb injuries/conditions. Each station will be approximately 7 minutes long. 

This exam will be conducted face-to-face, on-campus (St Lucia). 

Artificial Intelligence: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Feedback: You will receive individual written electronic feedback following the exam. If you would like further feedback, this request should be in writing to the course coordinator. Additional feedback will be provided within 14 calendar days. End-semester practical exam marks will not be released until after the release of the final grade.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The lectures will be delivered by Sports and Exercise or Musculoskeletal Physiotherapists with expertise in the management of lower limb injuries/conditions. The lectures provide information to develop understanding of pathology, assessment and treatment of patients with lower limb injuries and conditions. Lectures will be pre-recorded and available for you to view online. Refer to Blackboard for detailed schedule.

The lectures provide information to develop understanding of pathology, assessment and treatment of patients with lower limb injuries and conditions. Lectures will be pre-recorded and available for you to view online. Refer to Blackboard for detailed schedule.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

The tutorials in this course use problem-based learning activities to develop clinical reasoning in the management of lower limb injuries and conditions. Refer to Blackboard for detailed schedule.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Practical classes

In the practical classes, you will practice the practical skills in the course under the supervision of and with feedback from physiotherapy tutors. These classes will also contain standardised patient activities for you to integrate your skills and reasoning into a clinical context. Refer to Blackboard for detailed schedule.

These classes will also contain standardised patient activities for you to integrate your skills and reasoning into a clinical context. Refer to Blackboard for detailed schedule.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Recommended readings

There are recommended readings and accompanying study guides to increase your understanding of injuries and conditions affecting the lower limb. Refer to Blackboard for details.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Observational clinical placement

Students will undertake an observational clinical placement experience in the UQ Musculoskeletal and Sports Injury Clinic (MSSI). The aim of this learning activity is to provide students with an introductory experience working with physiotherapy clients in a private physiotherapy practice. Refer to Blackboard for details.
